article.title: Inedia
article.paragraph: File:J. Reynolds, A discourse upon prodigious abstinence... Wellcome L0022587.jpgrightthumb250px1669 report that claims a woman fasted for 12 monthsInedia(Latin for "fasting") orbreatharianismIPAc-enbrɛθˈɛəriənɪzəmis the belief that it is possible for a person to live without consumingfood. Breatharians claim that food, and in some caseswater, are not necessary for survival, and that humans can be sustained solely byprana, the vital life force inHinduism. According toAyurveda,sunlightis one of the main sources ofprana, and some practitioners believe that it is possible for a person to survive on sunlight alone. The termsbreatharianismorinediamay also refer to this philosophy when it is practiced as alifestyle (sociology)lifestylein place of the usualdiet (nutrition)diet.

Breatharianism is considered a lethalpseudoscienceby scientists and medical professionals, and several adherents of these practices have died from starvation and dehydration.cite newsUK: Scotland Woman 'starved herself to death' http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/scotland/453661.stm BBC 21 September 1999 10 March 2008 nocite webThree deaths linked to 'living on air' cult
Sunday Times (London) 26 September 1999 Tom Walker, Judith O'Reilly cite webhttp://www.nydailynews.com/life-style/health/swiss-women-dies-giving-water-food-thought-live-sunlight-article-1.1067359 Swiss woman dies after attempting to live on sunlight; Woman gave up food and water on spiritual journey 25 April 2012 [[Associated Press]] http://archive.is/xGmI32013-01-30no
article.heading: Scientific assessment
article.paragraph: Nutritionalscience proves thatfastingfor extended periods leads tostarvation,dehydration, and eventual death. In the absence of calorie intake, the body normally burns its own reserves of glycogen, body fat, and muscle. Breatharians claim that their bodies do not consume these reserves while fasting.cite webhttp://science.howstuffworks.com/innovation/edible-innovations/breatharian1.htmCan humans survive on air alone?HowStuffWorks, Inc.2009-07-30KatieLamberthttp://archive.is/MK2o2012-07-13no

article.heading: Ram Bahadur Bomjon
article.paragraph: Ram Bahadur Bomjonis a young Nepalese Buddhist monk who lives as an ascetic in a remote area of Nepal. Bomjon appears to go for periods of time without ingesting either food or water.cite news20 March 2006Nepalese Buddha Boy 'reappears'BBC Newscite webhttp://paldendorje.com/en/paldendorje.comhttp://archive.is/CRsf2012-07-12noOne such period was chronicled in a 2006 Discovery Channel documentaryThe Boy With Divine Powers, which reported that Bomjon neither moved, ate nor drank anything during 96 hours of filming.cite webhttps://archive.org/details/TheBoyWithDivinePowersThe Boy With Divine Powers
article.heading: Jasmuheen
article.paragraph: Jasmuheen(born Ellen Greve) was a prominent advocate of breatharianism in the 1990s. She claimed, "I can go for months and months without having anything at all other than a cup of tea. My body runs on a different kind of nourishment."cite bookThe Vegetarian Myth: Food, Justice, and Sustainability,Keith, L.9781604861822http://books.google.com/books?id2009PM PressInterviewers found her house stocked with food; Jasmuheen claimed the food was for her husband and daughter. In 1999, she volunteered to be monitored closely by theAustraliantelevision program60 Minutes (Australian TV program)60 Minutesfor one week without eating to demonstrate her methods.cite webhttp://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/60/stories/1999_10_24/story_57.aspLiving on air: Breatharian put to the testhttp://web.archive.org/web/20051102085047/http://sixtyminutes.ninemsn.com.au/60/stories/1999_10_24/story_57.asp2 November 2005cite webhttp://www.ratbags.com/rsoles/comment/jasmuheen.htmJasmuheen7 June 2008http://archive.is/jc2J2012-05-30noJasmuheen stated that she found it difficult on the third day of the test because the hotel room in which she was confined was located near a busy road, causingstress (medicine)stressandpollutionthat prevented absorption of required nutrients from the air. "I asked for fresh air. Seventy percent of my nutrients come from fresh air. I couldnt even breathe," she said. The third day the test was moved to a mountainside retreat where her condition continued to deteriorate. After Jasmuheen had fasted for four days, Dr. Berris Wink, president of the Queensland branch of the Australian Medical Association, urged her to stop the test.cite newshttp://www.caic.org.au/miscult/breatharians/Fresh-air%20dietician%20fails%20TV%20show%27s%20challenge.htmFresh-air dietician fails TV show's challenge[[Yahoo News]]25 October 19997 April 2015

According to Dr. Wink, Jasmuheens pupils were dilated, her speech was slow, and she was "quite dehydrated, probably over 10%, getting up to 11%". Towards the end of the test, she said, "Her pulse is about double what it was when she started. The risks if she goes any further are kidney failure.60 Minuteswould be culpable if they encouraged her to continue. She should stop now." The test was stopped. Dr. Wink said, "Unfortunately there are a few people who may believe what she says, and I'm sure it's only a few, but I think it's quite irresponsible for somebody to be trying to encourage others to do something that is so detrimental to their health."Jasmuheen challenged the results of the program, saying, "Look, 6,000 people have done this around the world without any problem."cite bookBergmanGregoryIsms: From Autoeroticism to Zoroastrianism – an Irreverent Referencehttp://books.google.com/books?id2006Adams Media1-4405-1788-632Though she claims thousands of people are tuned to this,cite webHarrisGillian6 April 2000Starvation guru given hostile receptionThe Timescite webhttp://liberatapublishers.com/mysticism.htmMysticism7 June 2008http://archive.is/Wxr52012-05-30nomostly in Germany,cite webSteinerSusie21 September 1999 Face behind food-free teachingThe Timesthere has been no verification that any have lived for extended periods without food.

Jasmuheen was awarded theBent Spoon AwardbyAustralian Skepticsin 2000 ("presented to the perpetrator of the most preposterous piece of paranormal or pseudoscientific piffle").cite webhttp://www.skeptics.com.au/spoon/2000winners.htmBent Spoon 2000 – Winner (Jasmuheen)7 June 2008https://web.archive.org/web/20050616014356/http://skeptics.com.au/spoon/2000winners.htm2005-06-16She also won the 2000Ig Nobel Prizefor Literature forLiving on Light. Jasmuheen claims that their beliefs are based on the writings and "more recentchannelling (mediumistic)channelledmaterial" fromSt. Germain (Theosophy)St. Germain.cite webhttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/uk_news/454313.stm22 September 1999All they need is the airBBC News11 January 2010http://archive.is/SyUd2012-07-11noShe stated that some people'sDNAhas expanded from 2 to 12 strands, to "absorb more hydrogen". When offered $30,000 to prove her claim with a blood test, she said that she didn't understand the relevance as she was not referring to herself.cite web1997http://www.abc.net.au/science/correx/archives/jasmuheen.htmCorrex Archives – JasmuheenCorexAustralian Broadcasting Corporation7 June 2008http://archive.is/SVCe2012-05-24no

In the documentaryNo Way to Heaventhe Swiss chemist Michael Werner claims to have followed the directions appearing on Jasmuheen's books, living for several years without food. The documentary also describes two attempts at scientific verification of his claims.citation neededJune 2014asof2012, four deaths had been directly linked to breatharianism as a result of Jasmuheen's publications.cite newsTomWalkerJudith O'ReillyThree deaths linked to 'living on air' cult[[The Sunday Times (UK)|The Sunday Times]](London)26 September 19992006-12-09cite newsSwiss woman starves to death on daylight diethttp://www.heraldsun.com.au/news/more-news/swiss-woman-starved-to-death-on-daylight-diet/story-e6frf7lf-1226339082591[[Herald Sun]]26 April 201226 April 2012"This was the fourth known death linked to breatharianism and Jasmuheen's books since the practice emerged in the early 90s."Jasmuheen has denied any responsibility for the deaths.
article.heading: Wiley Brooks
article.paragraph: Wiley Brooks is the founder of the Breatharian Institute of America. He was first introduced to the public in 1980 when appearing on the TV showThat's Incredible!.cite newshttp://community.seattletimes.nwsource.com/archive/?dateLiving On Light, Air – 'Breatharian' Says Food Is Poison But Pops An Occasional TwinkieSeattle TimesBroomJack5 October 199312 February 2009http://archive.is/rh3X82013-01-04noBrooks stopped teaching recently to "devote 100% of his time on solving the problem as to why he needed to eat some type of food to keep hisphysical bodyalive and allow hisSubtle bodylight bodyto manifest completely."cite webhttp://www.breatharian.com/WileyBrooks-altinate.htmhttp://web.archive.org/web/20060211031744/http://www.breatharian.com/WileyBrooks-altinate.htm11 February 2006Wiley Brooks website through Internet ArchiveWeb.archive.org11 February 200630 July 2009Brooks claims to have found "four major deterrents" which prevented him from living without food: "people pollution", "food pollution", "air pollution" and "electro pollution".

In 1983 he was reportedly observed leaving aSanta Cruz, CaliforniaSanta Cruz7-Elevenwith aSlurpee, ahot dogandTwinkies.cite webJohn Yewellhttp://www.metroactive.com/papers/cruz/01.05.00/nuzjunkies-0001.htmlA Year of NüzMetroActive News & Issues7 June 2008http://archive.is/ow372012-05-30noHe toldColors (magazine)Colorsmagazine in 2003 that he periodically breaks his fasting with acheeseburgerand acola, explaining that when he's surrounded by junk culture andjunk food, consuming them adds balance.cite webhttp://www.metroactive.com/papers/sonoma/02.13.03/diets-0307.htmlsonoma papersMetroactive.com30 July 2009http://archive.is/NRFs2012-05-30no

On his website, Brooks states that his potential followers must first prepare by combining the junk food diet with the meditative incantation of five magic "fifth-dimensional" words which appear on his website, some of which are words from Kundalini yoga.Five magic words download(MS Word document)cite webhttp://www.breatharian.com/fivemagicwords.htmlWiley Brooks website: Five magic wordsBreatharian.com30 July 2009http://archive.is/EnHeI2013-05-06noIn the "5D Q&A" section of his website Brooks claims that cows are fifth-dimensional (or higher) beings that help mankind achieve fifth-dimensional status by converting three-dimensional food to five-dimensional food (beef).Q and A five magic words
cite webhttp://www.breatharian.com/5wordsqa/holycows.htmlHoly cows sectionhttp://archive.is/6wM82012-09-12noIn the "Question and Answer" section of his website, Brooks explains that the "Double Quarter-Pounder with Cheese" meal fromMcDonald'spossesses a special "base frequency" and that he thus recommends it as occasional food for beginning breatharians.cite webhttp://www.breatharian.com/5wordsqa.html5 magic words Q&ABreatharian.com30 July 2009http://archive.is/7Adx82013-05-06noHe then goes on to reveal thatDiet Cokeis "liquid light".Prospective disciples are asked after some time following the junk food/magic word preparation to revisit his website in order to test if they can feel the magic.

Brooks states that he may be contacted on his fifth-dimensional phone in order to get the correct pronunciation of the five magic words.In case the line is busy, prospective recruits are asked to meditate on the five magic words for a few minutes, and then try calling again.

Brooks's institute has charged varying fees to prospective clients who wished to learn how to live without food, which have ranged from US$100,000 with an initial deposit of $10,000cite webhttp://www.breatharian.com/initiationworkshops.htmlWiley Brooks website: Initiation workshopsBreatharian.com30 July 2009http://archive.is/9mOva2013-05-06noto one billion dollars, to be paid via bankwire transferwith a preliminary deposit of $100,000, for a session called "Immortality workshop".cite webhttp://www.breatharian.com/immortalityworkshop.htmlImmortality workshophttp://archive.is/26Qq02013-05-06noRetrieved 21 November 2010A payment plan was also offered.cite webhttp://www.breatharian.com/initiationworkshops.html http://web.archive.org/web/20080213070205/http://www.breatharian.com/initiationworkshops.html13 February 2008 Initiation workshops from the Internet Archive Web.archive.org 13 February 2008 30 July 2009 These charges have typically been presented as limited time offers exclusively forbillionaires.cite webhttp://www.breatharian.com/WileyBrooks-altinate.htm http://web.archive.org/web/20060718084609/http://www.breatharian.com/WileyBrooks-altinate.htm18 February 2006 Fees via Internet archive Web.archive.org

article.heading: Hira Ratan Manek
article.paragraph: Hira Ratan Manek (born 12 September 1937) claims that since 18 June 1995 he has lived on water and occasionallytea,coffee, andbuttermilk. Manek states thatSungazingis the key to his healthcite webhttp://solarhealing.comSolar Healing Center6 February 2012http://archive.is/muRs2012-06-30nocitingYogis, ancientAncient EgyptEgyptians,Aztecs,Maya peoplesMayansandIndigenous peoples of the AmericasNative Americansas practitioners of the art.cite newsTimoshikAlexanderMan lives for 11 years eating only sunlighthttp://english.pravda.ru/science/mysteries/28-08-2006/84110-sunlight-0/24 February 201528 Aug 2006While he and his proponents state that medical experts have confirmed his ability to draw sustenance by gazing at the sun,cite newsK.SanthoshSharing their love for food, water, sunlighthttp://www.thehindu.com/2005/12/10/stories/2005121011610400.htm24 February 2015he was caught on camera eating a big meal in a San Francisco restaurant in the 2011 documentaryEat the Sun.cite webEat the Sunhttp://www.imdb.com/title/tt1424769/IMDb24 February 2015cite newsStorrWillThe man who lives without foodhttp://www.telegraph.co.uk/active/10032594/The-man-who-lives-without-food.html24 February 20156 May 2013
article.heading: Prahlad Jani ("Mataji")
article.paragraph: Prahlad Janiis an Indiansadhuwho has claimed to have lived without food and water for more than 70 years. His claims were investigated by doctors at Sterling Hospital,Ahmedabad,Gujaratin 2003 and 2010.cite newshttp://www.thehindu.com/news/national/article425184.eceThe Hindu – DIPAS concludes observational study on ‘Mataji'15 June 2010Manas Dasgupta9 May 2010http://archive.is/zF0td2013-02-03noThe research team reported that he did not consume any food or water during the testing periods, although they could not comment on his claim of having been able to survive in this way for decades.cite webhttp://www.dnaindia.com/india/report_experts-baffled-as-mataji-s-medical-reports-are-normal_1380169Experts baffled as Mataji's medical reports are normalhttp://archive.is/5q7I2012-07-24noThe study concluded that Prahlad Jani was able to survive under observation for two weeks without either food or water, and had passed nourineorfecesstool,cite newshttp://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/south_asia/3236118.stmFasting fakir flummoxes physicians7 June 2008Rajeev Khanna25 November 2003BBC Newshttp://archive.is/1Rtt2012-05-30nowith no need fordialysis.cite webhttp://abcnews.go.com/Health/International/man-eat-drink/story?idScientists Baffled by Prahlad Jani, Man Who Doesn't Eat or Drinkhttp://archive.is/kkpf2012-07-13noInterviews with the researchers speak of strict observation and relate that round-the-clock observation was ensured by multipleCCTVcameras. Jani was reportedly subjected to multiple medical tests.Jani's only contact with any form of fluid was during gargling and bathing, and the doctors said they measured the fluid that Jani spat out.

The case has attracted criticism, both after the 2003 tests and the recent 2010 tests.Sanal Edamaruku, president of theIndian Rationalist Association, criticized the 2010 experiment for allowing Jani to move out of a certain CCTV camera's field of view, meet devotees and leave the sealed test room to sunbathe. Edamaruku stated that the regular gargling and bathing activities were not sufficiently monitored,cite webEdamarukuSanalhttp://www.rationalistinternational.net/article/2010/20100518/en_1.htmlPrahlad Jani and his powerful protectorsRationalistinternational.net18 May 201014 June 2010http://archive.is/igdz2012-05-24noand accused Jani of having had some "influential protectors" who denied Edamaruku permission to inspect the project during its operation.
article.heading: Ray Maor
article.paragraph: In a television documentary produced by the Israeli televisionInvestigative journalisminvestigative showThe Real Face( ) hosted byAmnon Levy,Israelipractitioner of Inedia, Ray Maor ( ), appeared to survive without food or water for eight days and eight nights. According to the documentary, he was restricted to a small villa and placed under constant video surveillance, with medical supervision that included daily blood testing. The documentary claimed Maor was in good spirits throughout the experiment, lost 17 lb after eight days, blood tests showed no change before, during or after the experiment, andCardiologistIlan Kitsis fromTel Aviv Sourasky Medical Centerwas "baffled."<ref name="glz.co.il"/Valerya the "real life barbie doll" has recently converted to breathanarism.
article.heading: Religious traditions
Buddhism
Hinduism
article.paragraph: Hindu religious texts contain account of saints and hermits practicing what would be called inedia, breatharianism or Sustenance through Light in modern terms. In Valmiki'sRamayana, Book III, Canto VI, an account of anchorites and holy men is given, who flocked aroundRamawhen he came toarabhanga's hermitage. These included, among others, the "...saints who live on rays which moon and daystar give" and "those ... whose food the wave of air supplies". In Canto XI of the same book a hermit namedMakariis mentioned: "For he, great votarist, intent On strictest rule his stern life spent ... Ten thousand years on air he fed..." (English quotations are from Ralph T. H. Griffith's translation).
Paramahansa Yogananda'sAutobiography of a Yogidetails two alleged historical examples of breatharianism,Giri BalaandTherese Neumann.
There are claims thatDevraha Babalived without food.
